Sign up for coverage or change your plan at http://healthcare.gov.
The #AmericanRescuePlan provides a historic increase in the Child Tax Credit ‚Äî so that Virginia families will receive an extra boost as we accelerate the fight against this virus.

A family of four making $90,000 per year with a child over 6 and a newly eligible child age 17 or older:

Will receive $9,100 ‚Äî $5,600 in stimulus, a boost in the CTC of $1,000 plus $3,000 for the older child, minus the $500 credit for a dependent not receiving the CTC.

A family of four making $105,000 per year with one child under 6 and one child age 6 or older:

Will receive $8,200 ‚Äî direct stimulus payments of $5,600 and a boost in the CTC of $1,600 and $1,000, respectively.

A married couple making $40,000 per year with one child age 6 or older:

Will receive $5,200 ‚Äî $4,200 in direct stimulus payments plus a $1,000 boost in the CTC.

A married couple making $40,000 per year with one child under the age of 6:

Will receive $5,800 ‚Äî $4,200 in direct payments, plus a boost in the CTC of $1,600.

The #AmericanRescuePlan includes a major expansion of the Child Tax Credit for Virginia parents ‚Äî with payments beginning to arrive in July.

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúAgain, I want to thank all of you for your heroic efforts this past year. As we move forward, I am committed to crafting a bipartisan bill.‚Äù
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúSchool nutrition professionals feed kids healthy, nutritious meals each school day. I trust them to know their students and what will work in their schools.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúI continue to hear concerns about the school meals nutrition standards. In particular, the standards for milk, sodium and whole grains. The Arkansas School Nutrition Association recently described to me challenges they continue to face with these standards.‚Äù
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe pandemic has heightened the need for increased flexibility so that all options are on the table from off-site, grab-and-go models, to home delivery, to Summer EBT.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe Summer Food Service Program is hamstrung by rules that dictate a one-size-fits-all solution‚Äîrequiring children to travel to a central location and eat their meals together."

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúTwenty-two million children receive free or reduced-priced healthy meals during the school year through federal programs, but five out of six of these children are missing meals during the summer.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe Summer Food Service Program needs to be modernized to include flexibility in the congregate meals requirement to better ensure that our nation‚Äôs children are getting the nutrition they need to succeed.‚Äù
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúIt has been over 10 years since the last child nutrition reauthorization, and without a doubt, some of the programs need to be modernized.‚Äù
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúI have been a co-chair of the Senate Hunger Caucus for a number of years, so it is a priority of mine to see a child nutrition reauthorization bill cross the finish line.‚Äù

Sgt. Maj. Canley represents the very best of our men and women in our Armed Forces and exemplifies the spirit of all those who have answered the call to serve our country in uniform.
My office pursued the case and, in 2018, Sgt. Maj. Canley was awarded the Medal of Honor for his valor and decisive action in protecting his fellow brothers-in-arms.
In 2014, I was contacted by one of Sgt. Maj. Canley‚Äôs fellow servicemen who inquired about upgrading his award to the Medal of Honor ‚Äì the highest military award given by the U.S. government.
This advanced the war strategically and saved many American lives. For his extraordinary heroism, Sgt. Maj. Canley received the Navy Cross, as well as two Bronze Stars and a Purple Heart.

In 1968, during the Battle of Hue, his commanding officer was shot and gravely wounded. Then-Gunnery Sergeant Canley took immediate command of his company and directed several counter attacks over many long days under heavy fire.

On #MedalOfHonorDay, let us recognize the extraordinary service of Oxnard resident & Medal of Honor recipient Sergeant Major John Canley, whose brave actions during the Vietnam War saved the lives of many of his fellow Marines and played a critical role during the Tet Offensive. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExYEkquVgAYwNBX.jpg

After the war, Dr. Walker was awarded the Medal of Honor by President Andrew Johnson for her meritorious service in caring for sick and wounded soldiers, both in the field and hospitals. This #WomensHistoryMonth, we honor Dr. Mary Edwards Walker for her service.
After being held as a prisoner of war by Confederate troops, she became assistant surgeon of the Ohio 52nd Infantry.

Dr. Walker was not allowed to serve as a medical officer during the Civil War because she was a woman. However, she volunteered as an unpaid surgeon until her request to practice was granted in 1863 in Ohio ‚Äì becoming the first woman surgeon in the U.S. Army.

On this #MedalofHonorDay, the #WomensVetsTaskForce recognizes Dr. Mary Edwards Walker, who was a surgeon, abolitionist, women‚Äôs rights activist, and is still the only woman to receive the Medal of Honor. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExXXCH2VoAAvxk-.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExXW0tkVIAM2bHW.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExXW0syVcAAyoDu.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExXW1NKVgAAm8Mr.jpg

The history of health inequities in this country is a long and painful one, and comprehensive action is well overdue. We must take steps to not only address the inequities of this pandemic‚Äîbut to root inequity out of the health care system altogether.

Even as communities of color face more deaths & hospitalizations from COVID-19, they‚Äôre still getting vaccinated at lower rates than their white peers. The picture painted by the data so far is grim‚Äî& despite improvements, that picture is still incomplete. We‚Äôve got to fix that.

The reality of health inequities is that how you live‚Äîand even whether you live or die in a pandemic‚Äîis impacted by your race, income, zip code, disability, gender identity, sexual orientation, and more.

When we talk about inequities, we are talking about the reality that people‚Äôs health suffers because of systemic issues, like how far they are from quality, affordable, accessible, and culturally competent care.

Lastly, the economy as a whole benefits from a higher wage floor. 

More details here: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExV-OfiXEAwQtf-.png

Critics often present an increase in the minimum wage as bad for businesses, but even a $3.53 increase in just over 9 months in Seattle didn't lead to a decline in the rate at which businesses continued to open & the businesses survival rate was above 99%. https://www.budget.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Jacob%20Vigdor%20-%20Testimony%20-%20U.S.%20Senate%20Budget%20Committee%20Hearing.pdf
Further, an emerging body of evidence is finding that minimum wage increases are associated with positive public health effects. https://doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.3176217

Today‚Äôs federal minimum wage represents about one-third of the median wage for all full-time workers, and a gradual increase to $15 would lift minimum wage workers to above one-half of the projected median wage in 2025. https://www.epi.org/publication/raising-the-federal-minimum-wage-to-15-by-2025-would-lift-the-pay-of-32-million-workers/

In addition, states that raised their wage floor in 2019 had stronger wage growth at the bottom of the income distribution than their counterparts with no change in their minimum wage. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExV90U_W8AE0JSQ.png

Compared to states with no change to their minimum wage, states that raised their wage floor in 2019 experienced a larger rise in the share of adults working between 2018 and 2019. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExV9wQ8XMAQand7.png

In one of the largest studies of minimum wage increases in the United States, Cengiz et al. (2019) assess the impact of 138 state-level changes between 1979 and 2016. 

Some of their findings: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExV9vtYXAAcJzck.png

One of the things that critics ignore is the high degree of uncertainty surrounding the effect that raising the minimum wage would have on employment. 

For example, the @USCBO estimates that the effect could be zero. https://www.cbo.gov/system/files/2021-02/56975-Minimum-Wage.pdf

Critics argue that increasing the minimum wage to $15 by 2025 could potentially cost about 1% of U.S. workers their jobs.

But this representation argument ignores the latest research and evidence from states that have raised their wage floors.
